0.etymology_text:
For Proto-Italic *domos, from Proto-Indo-European *dá¹“m (â€œhouse, homeâ€), from root *dem- (â€œto buildâ€). Cognates include Ancient Greek Î´ÏŒÎ¼Î¿Ï‚ (dÃ³mos), Albanian dhomÃ« (â€œa chamber, a roomâ€), Avestan ğ¬›ğ¬€ğ¬¨- (dam-) Sanskrit à¤¦à¤® (dÃ¡ma), Proto-Slavic *domÑŠ and further to English timber. At least indirectly cognate to Latin dominus.
The feminine gender is probably due to the original root noun; attempts to transfer it to the 4th declension are due to 2nd declension feminines being unusual outside of tree names. Some manuscripts of Plautus show forms in dem-; De Vaan (2008) doubts their authenticity.
0.head_info_text: domus f (genitive domÅ«s or domÄ«); irregular, variously declined, fourth declension, second declension
